narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was an introduction to more complex python  and some basic programming: data structures, the python virtual machine, cryptography, etc.
Bunch of misc Python skills. List comprehensions, basic Object oriented programming, cryptography.
Learned Python, UNIX, shell scripts, also learned some other cool concepts like SQL, cryptography
Knowledge of coding in Python as well as various fundamental or useful CPSC skills like object oriented programming, recursion, databases, cryptography.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course covers a lot of interesting material and the PSETS teach you a lot. I do think the lecture format is dry and its hard to stay engaged when the entire hour fifteen is spent staring at a jupyter notebook

Strengths: Pretty straightforward class and lectures were all about conveying the information, Psets helped with learning the content, exams were easy if you did the Psets and went to/watched all the lectures, exams were also open notes, book, and computer which was nice, Psets also had tests to check if your code is working so you have an opportunity to get basically 100% on each pset

Weaknesses: Sometimes felt that you were teaching yourself to answer the Psets (you learn from doing them but they can be difficult, take a long time, and might require office hours and googling to figure out the algorithm you need to write), some questions didn't really test if you could code and were about finding the algorithm which was just googling and writing whatever program you find in python. Also exams were on days we didn't have lecture so we don't lost class time, which I think was unfair because you might have a packed off-day and have to self-schedule your midterms

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I dont know that there was much geared towards COVID-19 accommodations other than the recorded lectures- the professor did give us extra late days which made the load of the course much more manageable

Lectures were recorded, ample time for Psets (about two weeks), have late days to spend where you don't get points deducted for late submissions). What can be improved is that exams should be held within the class time or on the day of the class, replacing the lecture itself

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course is a great introduction to Python, so yes

Yes, take this class. It's a nice intro to Python. It might seem difficult for the first two Psets but stick it out, it gets MUCH easier after you actually learn some python and refresh your ability to write code (for people taking this as their first Yale CS class/only have AP CS as coding background). If you go to lecture and do the Psets, this class is an A

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lectures which were recorded and posted online afterwards
No other modes. Just live virtual lecture with recording
Lectures were also recorded and transcripts for the code Prof. Slade wrote in class were provided after each class
